title: How to Start a Conversation with a Guy on Facebook

steps.title: Check out his profile first.
steps.content: Check out his profile first. See what common interests you have before initiating a conversation, so you have something to talk about. [1] X Expert Source Maria Avgitidis Matchmaker & Dating Expert Expert Interview. 20 December 2019. If most of his profile is set to private, you can ask him about his favorite movie or book to help get the conversation started. [2] X Research source For instance, you could say, "I see your profile is set to private, so I'm curious why you're hiding your favorite book from people. What do you like to read?" Reader Poll: We asked 329 wikiHow readers how they initiate a conversation with a guy online, and 49% said talk about something on his profile. [Take Poll]

steps.title: Ask for help.
steps.content: Ask for help. Most people are willing to chat for a few minutes if you need some help. So ask for help with a problem you're having. If you don't actually have one, you could ask something about Facebook, such as the following: "I can never figure out how to break up my paragraphs in a post without making the post send. Do you know how to do that?" [3] X Research source

steps.title: Ask for recommendations.
steps.content: Ask for recommendations. If you're new to the area (or even if you're not), try asking him for restaurant recommendations as a way to open up the conversation. [4] X Research source Try asking a question such as "Hi, I'm new to the area. Can you recommend any good Japanese or Thai places in the area?" If he says yes, ask him if he'd be willing to meet you at one.

steps.title: Use fake recognition.
steps.content: Use fake recognition. That is, ask him if you've met him before. You can mention a place you go often. He'll say "no," but you can move on from there. [5] X Research source For instance, you could say, "Have I met you before? You look so familiar. Do you go the Panera Bread on 10th Street?"

steps.title: Make him laugh.
steps.content: Make him laugh. People love to laugh, so you can draw him in by making him laugh. The best jokes are ones that will connect you. [6] X Research source If you see he likes the same sports team as you, you could make a joke about how bad the team is doing, such as "I noticed you liked our local baseball team. They're doing so bad this year, I think my kid's little league team could beat them."

steps.title: Try a compliment.
steps.content: Try a compliment. People like to hear good things about themselves. Pick something you notice on his profile. [7] X Expert Source Maria Avgitidis Matchmaker & Dating Expert Expert Interview. 20 December 2019. It can be about his appearance, but it doesn't have to be. In fact, studies show that compliments not focused on appearance work best. You could comment on his taste in books: "You have great tastes in books! I loved The Ocean at the End of the Lane, too."

steps.title: Peruse his profile first.
steps.content: Peruse his profile first. Like starting a conversation for dating, you should always check out his profile for common ground, even if you're trying to become friends. If it doesn't have public information, ask him about it. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Keep it casual.
steps.content: Keep it casual. If you just want a friend, you don't want to send a signal that you want something more. [9] X Research source In other words, don't flirt. You don't want to comment it on his cute eyes if you just want to be friends.

steps.title: Try being straightforward.
steps.content: Try being straightforward. Say why you're contacting the person and what you want: "Hi, my name is Jake, and I'm looking for new friends in the area." [10] X Research source

steps.title: Ask him about himself.
steps.content: Ask him about himself. People like to talk about themselves, so ask him about what he likes and who he is. [11] X Research source As an example, you could say, "Hi, I noticed your profile today, and I found it interesting. Can you tell me more about yourself?"

steps.title: Use open-ended questions.
steps.content: Use open-ended questions. When beginning a conversation, open-ended questions (questions that require more than a "yes" or "no" to answer) encourage the conversation to continue. [12] X Research source For example, instead of asking "Do you like books?" ask him "What kind of books do you like to read?"

steps.title: Focus on common interests.
steps.content: Focus on common interests. For instance, if you both like basketball, focus on that. [13] X Research source For instance, you could say, "Hi, I'm Ashley. I see you love playing basketball. I love to shoot hoops, too. Did you play for your high school or college team?"

steps.title: Try an usual word as a greeting.
steps.content: Try an usual word as a greeting. That is, use "howdy" or "what's up?" as opposed to "hi" or "hello." Studies done by OkCupid show a person is more likely to respond to an unusual word.

steps.title: Look at his profile first.
steps.content: Look at his profile first. It's always important to have as many details as you can before starting a conversation with someone you don't know well. See where he works, what he does for a living, and where he lives. You can also look for common ground, such as similar interests or the fact that you both have two cats. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Focus on your connections.
steps.content: Focus on your connections. That is, if you are contacting person because he's a friend of a friend or because someone he knows recommended you chat, bring it up. [15] X Research source As an example, you could say, "I'm writing to you because Jeff Grace of ABC Financials suggested I get in touch with you."

steps.title: Ask about the person's job.
steps.content: Ask about the person's job. If you notice the person works in a similar field, ask about the job he does. [16] X Research source For instance, you could say, "Hi, I'm Jess. I notice you also work in engineering. I'm new to the field, so I was wondering if I could ask you some questions about your job."

steps.title: Tie the question to his location.
steps.content: Tie the question to his location. That is, tie in your location to initiate the conversation. [17] X Research source You could say, "Hi, I'm Beca. I'm new in Phoenix, and I was wondering if you have some time to talk about jobs in computer science in this area."

steps.title: Be straightforward about what you want.
steps.content: Be straightforward about what you want. If you're looking to make connections, mention that. If you're trying to find places that are hiring, ask about that. Most people are willing to help if you state what you want. [18] X Research source For example, you could say, "Hi, I'm new to the area, and I'm looking to make professional connections in my field. Do you mind chatting with me for a few minutes?"

steps.title: Always ask if the person has time to chat.
steps.content: Always ask if the person has time to chat. That is, make sure you're not interrupting anything. People may respond to you but not really have time for a drawn-out chat. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Back off if the person doesn't want to chat.
steps.content: Back off if the person doesn't want to chat. If the person makes it clear that he doesn't want to chat now, ask if you can chat in the future. If he says no, respect his wishes.

steps.title: Check your grammar.
steps.content: Check your grammar. Most people are turned off by bad grammar. Also, if you're over 20, avoid using "netspeak," such as "u" for "you" or "r" for "are."

steps.title: Stop trying to initiate conversation if he doesn't respond.
steps.content: Stop trying to initiate conversation if he doesn't respond. If you send a couple of messages and he doesn't respond, stop trying to initiate conversation, especially if your messages are marked "read" by the messenger.
